FIVE YOUNG MEN are passing a whiskey bottle around. Public Enemy playing on the CD player.
A Garda police car is parked in the road.
Garda Sergeant GERRY BOYLE behind the wheel. Staring off into space.
The red car zooms along at breakneck speed --
Eventually shooting past BOYLE in his police car --
BOYLE barely reacts -- Suddenly there comes the sound of screeching brakes, and the boom of a high-impact car crash -- BOYLE unhurriedly starts the car.

The red car has slammed straight into a side wall of the bridge. A YOUNG MAN has been thrown clear, the OTHER FOUR crushed inside the car. BOYLE drives up. Gets out beside the YOUNG MAN, who is covered in blood. He squats, putting a finger to the YOUNG MAN’s throat. He is dead. BOYLE approaches the concertinaed car.
CLOSE on BOYLE as he looks inside. He winces.
BOYLE returns to the YOUNG MAN. Goes through his pockets -- 10 (CONTINUED )

EXTREME CLOSE-UPS of cash, a condom and a small clear plastic bag containing two grams of coke, two Ecstasy tablets, and a tab of LSD with a smiley face. BOYLE replaces the cash and the condom, gets up and strolls over to the other side of the bridge. He fishes inside the plastic bag, takes out the LSD and swallows it -- EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the tab of LSD with a smiley face. He tosses the bag. Looks out over the water at the sunrise.
What a beautiful fucking day.

Skyscapes, with banks of cloud, low horizons.  13 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 3.
Garda AIDAN MCBRIDE waits by the door with two coffees. BOYLE drives up. Gets out, looks around -- TWO LITTLE GIRLS are looking on. MCBRIDE approaches BOYLE, holding out a coffee.
Who the fuck are you?
Aidan McBride, Sergeant.
Don’t know ya.
I’ve just been transferred from Dublin.
Big-city boy, hah? And here’s me, just a lowly country nobody.
“Lonely”?
Hah?
A “lonely country nobody”?
“Lowly”. “Lowly”.
Oh “lowly”. I thought you said “lonely”.
Not too sharp on the uptake, hah? You'll go far in this outfit. BOYLE takes the coffee from MCBRIDE, sips it, grimaces, and tosses it to the ground --
A fucking latte is my drink.
They told me cappuccino. BOYLE walks off, smiling to himself.  14 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 4.

A DEAD MAN slumped against a wall. Twenties, blond hair. A halo of blood and brain matter about his head from a single bullet wound. Pages from a book stuffed into his mouth. "5 1/2” painted in red on the wall above his head. A pot-plant balanced on his crotch. BOYLE and MCBRIDE survey the scene. A PHOTOGRAPHER taking photos with an archaic camera, the bulb popping.
What the fuck is he doing here?
He’s the scene-of-crime photographer. What do you--
Are you soft in the head or what? (to the PHOTOGRAPHER) Get out of here, Mick, before I tell your Mammy what you’ve been up to.
Sure it’s all good clean fun, Sergeant. I have what I need anyways. He pats his camera and hustles out the door just as BOYLE shapes to give him a kick. MCBRIDE looks puzzled.

I’m worried about that lad, now. He has an interest in the photographic arts that I can only describe as unhealthy. (examining the DEAD MAN) He looks like Brendan Foley. MCBRIDE produces a pad and pen, noting the name.
You know him?
I knew his auld fella. He ran off with my second cousin. I say “ran off”, the auld fella was ina wheelchair. He was a...what-d’ya- call-it?
Paraplegic? (CONTINUED)
14 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 5.
Spastic, yeah. (pause) Wheeled off. EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the name “Brendan Foley”, underlined.
Brendan Foley. I’11 get onto this--
I said he looked like Brendan Foley, I didn’t say it was Brendan Foley. MCBRIDE looks at BOYLE. EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the name “Brendan Foley”, crossed out.
This place is rented out to tourists.
I know. I’11 check with the woman in the office. I couldn’t see any ID here. BOYLE squats beside the DEAD MAN. He takes the pages from his mouth and studies them.
Ah...Should you, ah...Should you be removing those?
From the Bible, looks like. I knew there’d be a fucking religious angle. He tosses them aside. Looks at the DEAD MAN again.
He was a good-looking lad. Lovely lips. MCBRIDE shoots BOYLE a look.
The significance of the pot-plant has me somewhat perplexed.
Maybe it’s genus is a clue.
“Genus”, hah? Fancy. (CONTINUED )
14 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 6.
He removes the pot-plant. Places his hand on the DEAD MAN’s crotch and looks up at the ceiling, like some kind of weird psychic.
What the hell are you doing?
I have the gift. Did nobody tell ya? MCBRIDE is confused.
You never interfered with a corpse before? It’s great gas.
Ah now, listen, I don’t think--
I’m just messing. Lighten up, for fuck’s sake. He pats the DEAD MAN’s crotch. Stands up. Lights a cigarette.
I really don’t think that was appropriate.
Ah, would you fuck off to America with your “appropriate”, fucking Barack Obama.
I was only saying--
Any money in the house?
What? No. I mean, I haven’t checked.
You haven't checked if there’s any money in the house? What kind of a fucking guard are you, anyways? MCBRIDE is at a loss how to reply. BOYLE puts his hand to the wall --
Five and a half. (pause) Five and a half. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
(pause) Now what the fuck would that mean?
There’s a film called 8 1/2. Fellini. BOYLE looks blankly at him.
There’s another film called Se7en.

Are you just going to list a load of fucking film titles with numbers in them? I can do that, sure. Four for Texas. Robin and the Seven Hoods. Ten Thousand Bedrooms. Is that your idea of police work, hah?
I was only saying.
Well don’t say. He blows smoke rings.
Maybe this is the killer's five and a half...halfth victim.
(feigning interest) Go on.
Maybe he’s killed four people before now, and he’s maimed another lad. Cut off his legs maybe. Which would be the half. So this would be victim number five and a half.
Interesting theory. So what you're saying is, we may very well have a serial killer on our hands.
It’s a distinct possibility.
Well that'd be a first for Galway. Won't the big-city boys be jealous about that when they find out?
They will indeed. (CONTINUED )
14 15 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 8.
Not such a backward little town then, hah?
No indeed.
That’s right. Now go and see if there’s any money in the house. MCBRIDE looks blankly at BOYLE. Then turns and exits.

Fucking serial killer. The idiocy I have to deal with. INT. HOSPICE (DOCTOR OLEYUWO’S OFFICE) - DAY 15 BOYLE, in uniform, sitting opposite the hospice’s physician, Doctor MOSES OLEYUWO. Fifty, Nigerian, beautifully-tailored clothes. He is signing documents.
Six to eight weeks is the prognosis.
That’s what they told me.
That is how long she has, then.
She looks fine. Healthy.
It is not what is on the outside that counts, it is what is on the inside. Eating away at you.
I just want her to be comfortable, that’s all. OLEYUWO looks up. He signs a last document and closes the file. Caps his ink pen. Pockets it. Sits back in his chair and sighs.
I am sorry. I have been a little... You get like this sometimes in this line of work.
Sure don’t I know well. I have the same thing. (CONTINUED)
Next of kin?
Yeah.
You do not have that many murders here, surely?
Drunk drivers. Suicides.
Ah yes. Of course.
I don’t really give a fuck about the drunk drivers, to be honest. I’ve seen enough innocent people get killed. The suicides are tough, though.
What do you say to them? The family.
What can you say? You have to pretend to be sad, that’s the main thing.
I know. Pretending to be sad is what they pay me for, I always think.
Yeah. Like newsreaders.
I am sorry?

Newsreaders. They always put on their sad faces and lower their voices when they have to announce a calamity, as if they really give a shite. They’re all jolly at the end, then, as if nothing’s happened. OLEYUWO considers this. He nods.
I would never have made that analogy, but you are right. He opens a drawer, dips in a hand and, like a magician, produces a bottle of Maker’s Mark. (CONTINUED )
15 16 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 10.
Will you join me?
I will. OLEYUWO sets down the bottle, produces two glasses. Starts to pour. Pauses.
You would not know how to play Downfall, would you?
Downfall? OLEYUWO opens another drawer and, like a magician, produces Downfall, a children’s game from the ‘70s.
Oh. Yeah.
(extremely pleased) Yes? Very good. He and BOYLE move in closer to the desk and start setting up the game.
I used to play this game with my brother all the time, when we were children. He used to cheat, if you can believe this.
He used to cheat at Downfall?
I know. Some people, you know.
I know. It makes you wonder. They start to play.

EILEEN BOYLE, a robust-looking seventy-year-old, is sitting in the garden, reading a paperback. OTHER PATIENTS stroll dolefully about the grounds. BOYLE appears. Sits in the empty chair beside EILEEN. He glances around, then takes a packet of cigarettes from his pocket and passes them to her. EILEEN surreptitiously tucks away the cigarettes inside her voluminous clothing. (CONTINUED)

What are you reading? EILEEN shows him the book -- EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the Penguin paperback edition of Goncharov’s Oblomov.
Never got into the Russians. They take too long getting to the fucking point.

Ah come on, he was the main offender.

Overrated.
(after a pause) Pushkin’s Grandda was a black lad.

He went doolally in the end, though, God love him. BOYLE glances round, then takes a hip-flask from a side pocket and passes it to EILEEN. She quickly unscrews the top and takes a long swallow.
How are you settling in?
Alright, I suppose. They’re all so fucking boring.
Who are?
The inmates. Gloomy. She hands back the hip-flask. (CONTINUED )

There’s no need to make such a fucking song-and-dance about it. The OTHER PATIENTS traipse by them gloomily.
I see your point. Rubbing it in, like.
Rubbing it in is right.
(after a pause) How are those trainers suiting you?
They're the tops! She swings her feet up from under her, revealing a brand-new pair of white Reeboks.
Reeboks! She cackles wildly. BOYLE laughs. 17 INT. HANLEY’S BAR - DAY 17 BOYLE is drinking a pint and playing on a shoot-—’em-up games machine. MCBRIDE enters the bar, glances round, locates BOYLE.
Little early for a drink. BOYLE ignores him, keeps playing.
You're still on duty. BOYLE ignores him, keeps playing.
You've been gone all afternoon. BOYLE turns and levels MCBRIDE with a cold, dead, thousand-yard stare.
Are you going to continue to make a series of declarative statements, (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
or are you going to fucking tell me something? MCBRIDE is momentarily taken aback by the venom in BOYLE’s voice.
The murder over in Lettermore. The victim’s a John Doe. The--
Say that again?
The murder over in Lettermore? The victim’s a John Doe?
He’s a John Doe, is he?
Yeah. It means--
I know what it fucking means. Go on.
The name and address he gave were false, as far as we can make out. We've sent off his prints--
Anything else? You're boring the hole off me. He turns back to the shoot-’em-up game.

I got a call from Galway. You’re to head in tonight to attend a briefing from this fella who’s over from the FBI. (checking his notes) Special Agent Wendell Everett. He looks at BOYLE, expecting BOYLE to share his excitement.
So what?
Maybe it’s about the murder. Maybe he’s got a psychological profile on the killer or something.
It’s drug smuggling. (CONTINUED)
17 18 19 SHOOTING SCRIPT OCTOBER 9TH 2009 14.

But drug smuggling, I mean, that’s pretty exciting--

Yeah it’s fucking exciting. If you think standing on the fucking pier at Rossaveal in the pouring fucking vain for hours on end waiting for a fucking ship that’s never going to fucking arrive is fucking exciting. Go get me a pint.
Sorry?
Go get me a pint. Are you deaf? MCBRIDE is about to say something, but thinks better of it. He turns towards the bar. BOYLE keeps playing the shoot-’em-up game, his face a blank.
Two Garda cars parked outside. EUGENE MOLONEY -- a goofy nine-year-old, in a tracksuit -- wheelies past on his bicycle. He wheelies back -- And suddenly crashes to the ground. He groans in pain.

MCBRIDE is working at his computer. BOYLE has his feet up and is writing in a book -- EXTREME CLOSE-UP of a join-the-dots puzzle that reveals a rabbit. BOYLE nods, pleased. Shows the image to MCBRIDE.
Rabbit. (CONTINUED)

I’m not getting anything on any unsolved murders in the general vicinity. No maimings either.

Sergeant Gerry Boyle. Cop-shop!

BOYLE motions to MCBRIDE to pick up the extension. MCBRIDE does so, ever so gently.

Well done. Round of applause. Bouquet of red roses for the blue meanie. Anyways, it was Billy Devaney did for him. He’s into all that black magick. That's “magick” with a “k”. He told me last night when he was locked.

Bozo the fucking clown. 16. 21 (CONTINUED)

Ah man, he was doing my fucking head in. I was provoked, like. We were having a few jars, right, when he starts bringing up yet-a-fucking-gain this two hundred euros I owe him.
